title: This Amazon Basics Yoga Mat Is Thicker Than Expected (And That's Great)
metaDescription: Real talk about this thick NBR foam yoga mat - what works, what doesn't, and whether the carrying strap is actually useful for your practice.
content:
## First Impressions Matter

Right out of the box, this mat feels way more substantial than I expected from an Amazon Basics product. The thickness hits you immediately - we're talking serious cushioning here, not some flimsy piece of foam that'll compress after two sun salutations.

The NBR foam construction gives it a different feel compared to the typical rubber mats you see everywhere. It's softer underfoot but still maintains decent grip, which honestly surprised me. I was expecting something that felt cheap, but this actually holds its own.

## How It Handles Real Workouts

I've put this through everything from gentle yin sessions to sweaty vinyasa flows, and it performs better than you'd think. The extra thickness is a game-changer if you've got sensitive knees like me. Those warrior lunges that used to leave me wincing? Not anymore.

The grip situation is interesting. It's not as sticky as premium rubber mats, but it's not slippery either. You'll want to make sure your hands are dry, especially during more intense sessions. I found that once it warms up a bit from use, the traction improves noticeably.

Cleaning this thing is genuinely easy. A quick wipe with a damp cloth gets most stuff off, and for deeper cleaning, I've used mild soap without any issues. The NBR material doesn't seem to absorb odors the way some mats do, which is a huge plus.

## That Carrying Strap Situation

Let's talk about the elastic strap because it's actually pretty clever. It wraps around the rolled mat and keeps everything secure without being too tight. I've carried this thing to multiple classes and haven't had it come undone once.

The strap placement is smart too - it doesn't interfere with rolling or unrolling, and it stays put when you're using the mat. Small detail, but it shows someone actually thought about the user experience.

## What Could Be Better

The thickness that makes this mat so comfortable also makes it less stable for balancing poses. Tree pose feels a bit wobbly, and anything requiring serious balance work becomes more challenging. It's not a dealbreaker, but worth knowing if you're big on arm balances or standing poses.

The mat is also heavier than standard options. This won't matter if you're using it at home, but if you're walking or biking to yoga class, you'll definitely feel the extra weight.

I noticed some initial off-gassing when I first unrolled it. Nothing terrible, but there was definitely a foam smell that took a few days to dissipate completely.

## Who This Actually Works For

This mat shines for anyone who needs extra joint protection or prefers a softer surface. If you're dealing with knee issues, practicing on hard floors, or just like more cushioning, the thickness is genuinely beneficial.

Home practitioners will love this since portability isn't as crucial, and the easy cleaning makes it practical for regular use. It's also solid for beginners who might spend more time in seated or lying positions where the extra padding matters most.

However, if you're into advanced poses requiring maximum stability, or if you prefer the traditional feel of a thinner, stickier mat, this probably isn't your best bet.
pros: Genuinely thick padding protects joints well
NBR foam material cleans easily with just water
Elastic carrying strap stays secure and doesn't slip
Good grip once warmed up from use
Doesn't absorb odors like some foam materials
Soft surface reduces pressure on knees and wrists
Substantial feel that doesn't seem cheap or flimsy
cons: Extra thickness makes balancing poses more wobbly
Heavier than standard mats for carrying around
Initial foam smell that takes days to fade
Less sticky grip compared to premium rubber mats
verdict: This mat delivers where it matters most - comfort and durability at a reasonable price point. It's not perfect for every type of practice, but if you value joint protection over maximum stability, it's actually a solid choice.
targetAudience: Home practitioners, beginners, anyone with joint sensitivity, and people who prioritize comfort over portability in their yoga practice
